chapter.title: Cataloguing
chapter.para: Cataloguing refers to the processes involved in the creation of a library catalogue, which in turn enables searches, loans management, the compilation of statistics, ...
Note Whenever you see a "basket" icon displayed in the Cataloguing tab, you can add an item (record, copy, bulletin) to a basket by clicking on the icon . For more information, see .

sect2.title: All records
sect2.para: Search "all records" includes all PMB records : monographs, serials main entries, analytical entries
Search "serials" is effected only on main entries for serials.
"Recent additions" allows you to display the latest entries in the database.
PMB allows the use of boolean operators in search expressions. For more information, see .

sect4.title: Searching by title
sect4.para: The following screen appears when you click on the cataloguing tab. It allows searching and is always accessible in this module by clicking on "search" in the side menu.
Let's search for the title "cat".
If you have installed the test database, the book Catfish Blues by GÃ©rard Herzhaft is returned.
To display the full bibliographical entry for a work returned by the search, click on "+" to expand the entry and list all the copies (electronic copies as well) of the work.
Click on the title to display the catalogue details of the work, and if necessary to make any desired modifications. The screen display shows the list of all the copies of the work.

figure.title: List of copies of a work

sect4.para: To modify a record, click on Edit. To modify one of the copies of the work, click on its barcode. To add a copy, enter the item number then click on Add a copy. To add an electronic copy, click on Add an electronic copy. For more information, see .
The details mentioned at the bottom of the catalogue entry relate to the copies of the work, their availability, etc. Click on a copy barcode to make any modification.

sect4.title: Search by author, ISBN, EAN or item number
sect4.para: Search by author works exactly like search by title.
You can also search for a document by its ISBN, commercial barcode (EAN) or item number.
Finally, you can refine your search by limiting it to specific document types.

sect3.title: Subject/Class number
sect3.para: The available subject classes are displayed (you can modify them in the authority tab).
Click on the folder icon to open the subject class and possibly display the sub-classes.
When you have reached the desired class or sub-class, click on its name to display the results.

figure.title: Cataloguing > records > search by subject/class number

sect3.title: Keywords
sect3.para: Searching by keywords allows you to navigate amongst the thesaurus terms.

Cataloguing > works > search by keywords
To search by keywords, first enter one or more keywords you want to search, for example, history. The results are displayed in two areas in the central interface. The upper area displays subjects related to your search. Click on any one of them (for example political history) to display more details in the bottom area.
Click on the links to navigate from subject to subject.

To select a subject and display related works, click on the magnifying glass at the beginning of the line if the database does not contain any works under a keyword, the magnifying glass is not visible.

sect3.title: Publisher/Series
sect3.para: The Publisher/series search displays publishers and series exactly like the keywords search.

sect3.title: Baskets
sect3.para: Search in > Baskets allows to display the contents of a basket (also referred to as a "caddy"). Baskets correspond to a selection of records, bulletins or copies.

sect3.title: Advanced search
sect3.para: Advanced search offers to search using a combination of various access points. You can select fields to search in : title, author, personalized search fields...
To start an advanced search :

listitem.para: Click on Add to define a first search criteria
Advanced search applies to access points of records, copies, periodicals and personalized fields.

Next select a search type for the desired field, you can choose among "Booleean expression", "Contains one of the words", "Contains all the words", "Starts with", "Ends with", or "Exactly like". This type of search varies depending on the field selected
Types of search in Title

If the field requires a value, enter it into the textbox; if it requires a choice (for example the type of media), click to select one or more options while maintaining the Ctrl key of your keyboard down.
Finally click on Search to validate

sect3.title: Boolean Expressions
sect3.para: You can use boolean expressions with all the search screens. Boolean expressions were introduced in PMB with version 2.0.

sect4.title: Simple search
sect4.para: By default, the engine looks for records containing at least (OR implicit) one of the words entered. Sorting is done by descending order on the number of word hits then alphabetically.
For example cheddar cheese returns records containing the words cheddar OR cheese (Cheddar cheese, Red Leicester cheese, The history of the Cheddar region, ...).
Accented characters are ignored, uppercase words as well. If two words are separated by another sign other than space, +, or -, both words will appear in the search result.
For example Santa Cruz/seawill be analyzed as : find records containing Santa OR records containing Cruz AND sea OR both.
Some words are ignored because too frequent or having no significant meaning in English (e.g. : a, if, in, of, on, the, that, to, ...). They are referred to as stop words.

sect4.title: The minus sign
sect4.para: The minus sign - is considered as an operator when placed in-between two words (see the chapter : Logical operators in-between words). Hence compound words must be surrounded by quotes for an exact term search, (see further below).

sect4.title: Truncation
sect4.para: Words can be truncated to the left, right or partially using the * sign.
For example hor* will search for words starting with "hor" (horde, horizon, horse, ...),
*logywill search for words ending with "logy" (psychology, theology, trilogy, ...),
p*logy will search for words starting with "p" and ending with "logy" (psychology, paleonthology, pathology, ...).
Several truncations can be used within one and same word.

sect4.title: Searching exact terms
sect4.para: An exact term is defined as a text enclosed in quotation marks. Whenever the search engine encounters an exact term, it searches for records containing this term.
Truncation can be used within exact terms.
For example "dent"will return all records containing the term dent (dentist, accident, indentation, ...).
Exact term searching is convenient for search expressions containing spaces or punctuation marks. (an acronym for instance).
For example "W.W.F." searches for records containing the text W.W.F.,
W.W.F. searches for records containing the letters W or F.
Accents and uppercase are ignored in an exact term.
Finally exact terms can be used in all complex expressions as described further below.

sect4.title: Negation
sect4.para: The "~" sign in front of a term represents the negation of the term. It actually means search for all records not containing that term.
for example ~work means all records except those containing the word "work"

sect4.title: Logical operators in-between two words
sect4.para: Logical operators can be used in-between words :

listitem.para: + : AND operator
For example hard + disk means all records containing the words hard AND disk.
- : NOT operator
For example hard - disk returns records containing the word disk, except those containing also the word hard.

sect4.para: Several operators may be chained together in one and same equation or search expression. The precedence order applied is from left to right.
For example poetry + french - romantic* will return records containing poetry AND french NOT romantic(s).
Caution, two operators cannot be placed immediately one after another, a negation cannot be combined with another operator (+~ expresses the same thing as the operator -).

sect4.title: Groupings
sect4.para: An expression can be grouped to become a single term. Groupings are made using parentheses. This makes it possible to change the order of precedence in the application of operators or to combine the results of complex search expressions or equations.

listitem.para: means in all records containing the words french OR romantic, only those containing the word poetry.
(french + poetry) romanticmeans means all records containing poetry AND french OR all records containing the word romantic

~(french + poetry) + (ameri* literature) means all records NOT containing the words poetry AND french AND records containing the words literature OR ameri*. Parentheses Parentheses can be imbricated with one another endlessly.
(poetry + (french romantic)) (literature + XIX)means in all records containing french OR romantic, only those containing poetry OR records containing literature AND XIX

sect4.title: Relevance
sect4.para: Results are sorted by relevance and then alphabetically. Relevance is calculated simply on the total number of words or exact terms hits.
For example :

listitem.para: lobster maine will recall all records containing french OR poetry, those containing both words being displayed on top.

~(french + poetry) (ameri* literature) will recall all records not containing poetry AND french, from these records, those containing literature OR ameri* appearing on top in the results (first literature AND ameri*, then ameri*, and finally literature)

sect2.title: Serials
sect2.para: For more details on Serials management, consult the section Serials > New serial.
Search all records enables you to search the entire catalogue, including articles and serials.
Search serials allows you to recall a particular periodical entry immediately so you can add a newly received issue for example, or to resume the indexing of articles of a given issue.
PMB allows you to use regular expressions as search criterias. For more information, see .
For more details on a search result, click on the "+" in front of the title.
To display a given serial, click on its title from among the search results. The serial entry is displayed on screen. For more information, consult the section 2.3.2 Displaying a serial.

Note Only main entries of serials are displayed in the search results: for example, Newsweek, The Economist, Time; articles as well as the various issues of serials are not returned by a search but on the Issues screen, go to the section 2.3.3 Issues.

sect2.title: Recent additions
sect2.para: This element allows you to access the latest entries.
Recalling recently added records allows the librarian to rapidly find an entry for correction, for entering details not recorded previously...

sect3.title: Adding a new record
sect3.para: Adding a new record is a two-screen operation : first PMB asks for an identification number (ISBN), but it is not compulsory to enter it. If a EAN is entered, it is converted into an ISBN.

sect4.title: Entering ISBN, EAN or commercial number
sect4.para: If the identification number entered corresponds to an existing work in the database, the bibliographic record is opened in edit mode directly. This allows you to avoid the duplication of records when cataloguing.
Then click on Next to continue to the next screen.

sect4.title: Entering data

sect5.title: Choosing a material dsignation
sect5.para: In the drop down list at the top of the fill-in form, you can choose from among various material designations :

listitem.para: printed text
manuscript text
musical score - printed
musical score - manuscript
cartographic document - printed
cartographic document - manuscript
video, projectable document
sound recording - non musical
sound recording - musical
2D graphical document
electronic document
multimedia document
3D object, artifact, ...

sect5.para: These material designations correspond to UNIMARC standards.
Warning : do not mistake them for media types which correspond to the copy.

sect5.title: Title entry
sect5.para: The title proper is the principal title of a work.

Even when the title is printed on the cover or on a section of the work, you must transcribe it from the title page as it is sometimes different from the cover title. In this case the cover title will be indicated elsewhere (note zone).
You can also define the title proper of a different author, a parallel title and other title information.
Parallel titles are, for instance, titles of works in their original language.

Finally you can define collective titles. A collective title is a title common to various works of the same author. For example The Adventures of Flash Gordon by Alex Raymond. The field "Part of" is different from the "title" fields. To specify a title for a collection, click on the button "..."
Next select a title for the collection in the pop-up.

If the title of your collection is not in the pop-up list, click on Add collection. Next enter the title, click on Save and finally select your collection from the list. You cannot modify or delete a collection in the pop-up. To do so, in the tab Authority, select collection in the menu. For more information, see .
The selected collection is then displayed in the record fill-in form.
To remove a selected collective title, click on the "X" button
You can also specify a part number. For instance, The Adventures of Flash Gordon, number 11.

sect5.title: Author entry (statement of responsibility)
sect5.para: To select an author, click on the button "..." then select the author in the search author pop-up. To search for an author, enter the first letters of his/her last name and click on Search. The results of the search are then displayed.

figure.title: Cataloguing > New record, select author pop-up

sect5.para: If the author of a work you are cataloguing is not yet registered, you can add him/her by clicking on the button Add author.

figure.title: Cataloguing > New record, adding an author from the pop-up

sect5.para: You can add a new author either during the cataloguing process or in the "authorities" tab. For more information on adding authors, see .

If "author" is the appropriate term for the writer of a book, it is not the same thing for a film when the title of "Director" would be more appropriate. The term used then refers to the function of the author in relation to the type of work. To select a function (not mandatory), click on the button "...".
A few observations :

listitem.para: There can only be one primary author for a work, but there can be coauthors, and/or secondary authors. To select a coauthor or a secondary author click on the corresponding "..." button. To add an additional author, click on the "+" button.
to remove an author or a function, click on the "X" button

sect5.title: Publisher entry, series, sub-series and collective titles
sect5.para: Entries for series, sub-series, and collective titles are made when creating or editing records (data entry only), or in the Authority tab. Start with sub-series if necessary, otherwise series or finallypublisher.
In the select sub-series pop-up, select a sub-series or else click on Add sub-series, fill-in the known fields then click on the select "mother" series button of the sub-series.
In the select series pop-up containing our sub-series, select a series or choose Add series, fill-in the known fields except the publisher, then click on the select publisher button.
In the select publisher pop-up, select a publisher or choose Add publisher and complete the entry.
Once the entry is completed, select the publisher of the series, then the series containing our sub-series, and finally save the sub-series and select it.
In general, choose the more specific element first. Choose the sub-series, then the series and in the end the publisher.
A series corresponds to a publishers' choice : Penguin Books, Rough Guide series
A sub-series answers to the same concern but at a higher level: Oxford University Press, Oxford Handbooks 8, sub-series History.
A collection is a work published in a set of volumes under a collective title, each volume bearing its own title.
Example Tolkien, J.R.R. Collective title The Lord of the Rings part Number Book III Title proper The Return of the King

To make this entry, you must first create the collection and the collective title in PMB before selecting them. The part number and the title proper must be entered when creating the record of the work.

sect5.title: ISBN, EAN or commercial number
sect5.para: The ISBN, which was asked in the first screen of the new record entry, is displayed here. Click on the "..." button to open a pop-up either for scanning the EAN of the work or for entering its ISBN. The entry is done via a pop-up to avoid closing a new record entry in edit mode after validation of a barcode scan.
PMB automatically converts EANs (commercial barcodes) into ISBN.

sect5.title: Collation
sect5.para: The collation area details various information related to the physical aspect of the document : extent of item (number of volumes, pagination), illustrations, format, price, accompanying materials.

sect5.title: Notes
sect5.para: There are three types of notes : General, Contents-linked (critical appraisal), and a Summary, an Excerpt of the document (for instance, the summary of a novel on the outside back cover).

sect5.title: Indexing
sect5.para: The indexing area is made up of three elements :

listitem.para: Subject headings : add a subject from the PMB internal thesaurus. For more information about subject headings, see .
To select a subject, click on the "..." button. To enter an additional subject, click on the "+" button. To remove a selected subject, click on the "X" button.

figure.title: Cataloguing > New record, select subject pop-up

listitem.para: To create a subject heading, click on the Add button.
Classification : adding a class number. For more information, consult the chapter Authority, section Classification.

Free indexing : here you can freely enter keywords, separated by spaces. You can, for instance, specify keywords, or use the index a thesaurus not integrated into PMB (Sears subject headings, for example).

sect5.title: Language of publication
sect5.para: Here you can specify the original language of the publication, defined by default in the user's preferences. For more information, consult the chapter User preferences.
The language codes are defined by the UNIMARC standard.
If the document is a translation, you can define the original language.

figure.title: Cataloguing > New record, Language of publication area

sect5.title: Links (electronic ressources)
sect5.para: The associated URL must be entered fully (including http://) to ensure that the link will function with any internet browser.
The electronic format can be chosen freely by the cataloguer. Prefer field entries using the term "file", for instance "PDF file" or "Acrobat File", and generic indications such as : "internet site".

Advanced : RSS feeds. You can also link an RSS feed to a record. An RSS feed is a round-the-clock information flux broadcasted by an internet site. The RSS feeds of the BBC news site, news.bbc.co.uk, bring you the latest headlines of the site. By tying an RSS feed to an entry describing the BBC news site, you enable the readers of your library or documentation centre to access the latest BBC news from your OPAC.

To link an RSS feed, enter the corresponding URL (you can easily find the information on the web) into the associated URL field. Enter RSS NN as the electronic format, NN being a number in minutes defining the news refresh rate. For example, if you enter "RSS 30", the corresponding RSS feeds will be refreshed every 30 minutes. These information will be cached, accelerating the PMB OPAC responses for the next 30 minutes.

sect5.title: Custom fields
sect5.para: Finally, at the bottom of the record you can define your custom fields.

The customizable fields of records contain additional information, you can create them in Administration > Records > Customizable. For more information, consult the Administrator's Guide, chapter Records.
If no custom fields were defined, this area will not be displayed.

figure.title: Cataloguing > New record, Custom fields area

sect4.para: Once the various fields of the record are filled, click on Save. The record is saved, and you come to the list of copies of the document.

sect3.title: List of copies of a document
sect3.para: The next screen shows the ISBN formatted record together with corresponding copies, if any.

figure.title: Cataloguing > Works, list of copies of a document

sect3.para: To modify a record, click on Edit. The modification and creation operations open the same screen.
You can Add a copy.
You can also Add an electronic document.
If the record already contains copies, you can edit them by clicking on the copies' number.
If the record already contains electronic copies, you can display and modify them. To display e-copies click on the icon, to modify them click on the title.

sect4.title: Modifying a record
sect4.para: To modify a record, click on the "Edit" button at the bottom of the entry just above above the associated copies list.
In edit mode a record displays the same fill-in form as a new record's (consult the section 1.2.1.2, Adding a new record). However you will also find additional buttons at the bottom of the screen.

figure.title: Buttons available at the bottom of the "Modifying a record" screen

sect5.title: Replace with
sect5.para: Makes it possible to replace a record by another, this allows you to remove duplicates and gather copies linked with various double entries.

sect5.title: Duplicate
sect5.para: Allows the duplication of a record. A new record is displayed, enter changes to be made on the original entry relevant to the document being catalogued and save the new record.
This function is very useful for cataloguing complete series or collections.

sect5.title: Hist.
sect5.para: This button is displayed only when the audit of records and copies is enabled. It makes it possible to see the name of the user who made the catalogue entry, and who made any modifications. The information is displayed in a pop-up and depends on the audit type level. For more information, consult the PMB Administrator's Guide, Tools, Parameters, type_audit in "General Parameters".

sect5.title: Z39.50
sect5.para: Allows you to search for a record using the Z39.50 search function. This button launches a new search on the ISBN of the displayed record.

sect5.title: Delete
sect5.para: Allows you to delete a record. Warning, you can delete a record only if it does not have any associated copies (hard or electronic).

sect4.title: Adding a new copy
sect4.para: To modify one of the copies of the document, click on its barcode. To add a copy, enter the item number then click on Add a copy.

figure.title: Adding a new copy : entering the item number

sect4.para: The item number is the barcode you placed on the cover, if you are using a barcode reader. Else it is then a distinct number given to every item of your library (accession number).
The "add a copy" screen allows you to enter various data:

listitem.para: the item number is displayed. This data is mandatory. To modify it click on the "..." button and scan the barcode number of the copy into the pop-up (or enter a new item number then validate).
enter acall number. This information is mandatory. The call number is often made up of the decimal notation followed by the first three letters of the author's name.
select the media type in the drop-down list. The list of the document types is configurable in Administration > Items > Media types.
select the location in the drop-down list. The location list is configurable in Administration > Items > Locations.
select the section in the drop-down list. The sections list is configurable in Administration > Items > Sections.

select theowner of the copy in the drop-down list. The owners list is configurable in Administration > Items > Owners. Generally, it is your library's holdings. However you can have a deposit from your main County Public Library or from another library.
select the status of the copy in the drop-down list. The status list is configurable in Administration > Items > Status .
select the statistical code of the copy in the drop-down list.
you can also define for notes a message related to the copy. This message will be displayed before any loan. For example : "ASSIMIL method, please check that the case contains 3 cds".
finally you can define a price.

sect4.para: Some of these entry fields can have default values defined in your user preferences. For more information, consult the chapter User preferences.

Below price are located the custom fields of the copy. They represent additional data that you can define in Administration > Items > Customization. For more information, consult the PMB administrator's Guide, Copies.
To save your modifications click on Save else Cancel. If you have opened a copy in edit mode you can also Delete it.

sect4.title: Adding an electronic copy
sect4.para: Electronic copies or e-copies are not links, but actual digital documents directly integrated in your catalogue in PMB. You can thus add to your catalogue as many types of digitized documents : PDF, MP3, text, spreadsheet, pictures...
You can define various information :

listitem.para: the name of the document
the file of the digital document. Click on the button Browse and select the file you wish to upload to the server.
a thumbnail (the image for the electronic document icon). Click on the button Browse and select the file you wish to upload to the server.
you can also upload an external file from your intranet or the internet. In this case specify the URL of the file.

sect4.para: PMB generates thumbnails automatically from GIF, PDF, JPG and PNG files, and uses the appropriate icons for most of the file formats.
To save your modifications click on Save else Delete. If you have opened an e-copy in edit mode, you can also Delete it.

sect4.title: Modifying a copy
sect4.para: Modification and add screens are almost identical, the former has two additional buttons : Hist. and Delete.

sect5.title: Hist.
sect5.para: This button is displayed only when the audit of records and copies is enabled. It makes it possible to see the name of the user who made the catalogue entry, and who made any modifications. The information is displayed in a pop-up and depends on the audit type level. For more information, consult the PMB Administrator's Guide, Tools, Parameters, type_audit in "General Parameters".

sect5.title: Delete
sect5.para: Allows you to delete the displayed copy. Warning, a copy cannot be deleted if it is currently on loan.

sect4.title: Modifying an e-copy
sect4.para: The modification screen of an e-copy is identical to the add an electronic copy screen.

sect3.title: Cataloguuing special records
sect3.para: PMB allows you to catalogue not only books and periodicals, but also your multimedia kits, websites, RSS fluxes...

sect4.title: Cataloguing a website
sect4.para: To catalogue a website, define the material designation as electronic document. Enter a title proper for your record. In the links (electronic resources) area, enter the associated URL (use the format http://www.bbc.co.uk). In electronic format for this resource, you can enter website.

sect4.title: Cataloguing an RSS flux

para.remark: Note PMB can also generate an RSS flux from a basket or a virtual shelf. You can load a basket by means of the Selective Dissemination of Information (SDI). For more details on adding an RSS flux, consult .

sect4.para: "An RSS feed, acronym for Really Simple Syndication or Rich Site Summary is a format for syndicating Website contents. The system is used by news-oriented websites and weblogs to publish their headlines and web-contents enabling users to consult them immediately without having to visit the websites themselves" (source : http://http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSS).
To catalogue an RSS, enter a title for the RSS feed. In links, copy-paste the URL of the RSS feed. In electronic format for this resource, enter "RSS ### #" with :

listitem.para: RSS : for PMB to display the web-contents of the URL, enter the XML file correctly
### : for the cache period, enter 30 for 30 minutes, for instance
# : 0 or 1 to publish the RSS feed on the Home page or not

sect4.para: To display RSS feeds on the OPAC Home page, define the parameter opac show_rss_browser 1. For more information on customizing PMB, consult the PMB Administrator's Guide, Tools.

sect1.title: Serials
sect1.para: PMB allows the entry of general information about periodicals; for instance, details regarding the most recent issue or articles in the issue.

sect2.title: Vocabulary
sect2.para: By serials we mean any publication (including non-print material) generally appearing at regular or irregular intervals under a uniform title.
You need to know the meaning of four terms to understand how PMB manages serials :

listitem.para: the serial is defined in PMB by a record (called "mother" record or main entry) establishing the title of the publication, of the magazine, etc. This record describes the serial or periodical on a general level : Le Monde is a daily newspaper, founded by Beuve-MÃ©ry.

the issue (also called bulletin) identifies, for instance, the issue numbered 32478 dated 15 August 2002of Le Monde. Cataloguing a periodical means describing all the individual issues and associated copies so they can be loaned or analytical entries of articles can be made.
the copy corresponds to the physical aspect of an issue. If you have two subscriptions to Le Monde, you'll have in your holdings two copies of the issue numbered32478.

the article (also called content) forms the basis of the various issues of a periodical. Articles can be described and catalogued, and therefore can be described in a record. For example : an article published on page 10 of Le Monde, 18 June 2003, can be catalogued.

sect2.para: Let's recap : We subscribe to the daily Le Monde (a periodical entry ), with an issue) numbered 32478 of which we possess two copies in the library (two items with two distinct barcode numbers for loans). In the issue, there are fifty major articles that the readers and librarians can search independently, each one relating to the corresponding issue and to the availability of the corresponding copies.

If no entry exists in PMB yet, the periodical article entry is made in a few different steps : add a new periodical entry, list current issues, create copies if any, make an analytical entry for the article.

figure.title: Browsing the display screens of periodicals

sect2.para: When you display the record entry of a periodical (here GÃ©o), of one of its issues (here issue number278) or of one of the articles of this issue, a navigation bar is appears on top of the screen. This bar allows you to rapidly go to the upper level in the periodical record exploration.

sect3.title: Adding a serial
sect3.para: Let's describe in detail how to add a new serial. In the Cataloguing tab, click on New serial in the side menu.

sect4.title: Material designation
sect4.para: PMB can manage various serials formats. The printed form (newspapers, magazines, reviews) is the most common, but PMB can also manage talking newspapers for the blind and visually impaired persons, electronic periodicals, etc.
The 13 formats of the drop-down list are normalized to UNIMARC standards :

listitem.para: printed text
manuscript text
musical score - printed
musical score - manuscript
cartographic document - printed
cartographic document - manuscript
video, projectable document
sound recording - non musical
sound recording - musical
2D graphical document
electronic document
multimedia document
3D object, artifact, ...

sect4.title: Other entry fields
sect4.para: The other entry fields for a periodical correspond to those of a work. See above section 1.2.1 Adding a new record.
Note It is not possible to define collation (number of pages, accompanying materials, ...) for a periodical. Similarly the notion of series does not apply for periodicals.
After saving your periodical record, you get the screen Serials: Display items.

sect3.title: Displaying a serial
sect3.para: From this screen you can modify the periodical record by clicking on the Edit button. Modifying a periodical entry is similar to adding a new periodiacl. See below the section New serial.
You can Delete the periodical.
You can add an issue as well.

In the list of issues displayed underneath the main entry in the lower half of the screen, each line shows for a given issue the Issue number, the Date of issue or period, the number of articles Art, the number of E-copies, and the number of Hardcopies
You can display an issue by clicking on any one line in the list of issues. The issue is then displayed on the screen Serials: issue(s).

sect4.title: Adding a new issue
sect4.para: Only the following data are required : the issue number (32478), the issue barcode, the period and/or date of issue, and finally the title of the issue.
Numbering : is used to store the issue number. For instance the number 153 of the periodical.
Barcode : it allows you to enter the issue barcode, for example 3792578022009.

Date of issue is used to enter the date of publication of the issue (01/06/04). The date is used as sorting order for the display of issues. If no date is entered, either manually or using the calendar pop-up by clicking on calendar, PMB will automatically fill it with the current date.
Period entry field : this field is used to enter the publication date as printed on the issue : for example June-July 2006.
Title of issue : it is used to enter the title of a given issue, for example special : climate change.

sect4.title: Managing issues
sect4.para: From this screen you can :

listitem.para: Modify or Delete the issue
Modify a copy in the issues' list of copies by clicking on its barcode
Display an e-copy by clicking on its icon, or modify it by clicking on its title
Add a copy by entering its copy number and clicking on Add a copy
Add an article entry to the issue

sect4.para: The list of articles is displayed in the lower half the screen.
For more details, click the "+" icon at the start of the line.
To modify an article entry click on its title.
To add an electronic document to an article click on the Add an eletronic document button located in the article details.

sect5.title: Adding a copy to an issue
sect5.para: See above the section 1.2.2.1 on how to create a copy of a document Adding a copy . Adding copies to an issue is similar.

sect5.title: Adding an e-copy to an issue
sect5.para: See above the section 1.2.2.2 on how to create an electronic document Adding an electronic document. Adding e-copies to an issue is similar.

sect5.title: Adding articles
sect5.para: The article record corresponds to a standard record but with an additional feature: pagination.
Note : You cannot add a title proper from another author to an article.
Cataloguers are advised to follow the following conventions :

listitem.para: p. X article on page X
pp. X-Y article from pages X to Y
pp. X-Y, Z, AA-AC article separated in three groups of pages : from pages X to Y, on page Z, from pages AA to AC

sect5.para: To these conventions, it is also possible to add column information, generally by specifying col. then a, b or c for the column position.

sect1.title: Baskets
sect1.para: The baskets are PMB storage space : you can fill them with records, periodical issues, copies.

In PMB you can use the baskets, for instance, for stocktaking : it is a library term for inventory. Baskets can also be used for weeding : withdrawing from the collection works that are too old or damaged beyond repair.
You can also use baskets to store bibliographies : results of various searches to be used for a write-up, a subject catalogue,...
There are two ways to fill a basket : by entering elements manually (look for the basket icon), or by scanning/entering the barcode.

sect2.title: Management
sect2.para: By default, in the submenu Baskets/Management, the screen displays the manage baskets function. You can display the manage procedures function by clicking on the link provided.

sect3.title: Managing baskets
sect3.para: Click on the basket name to display its contents. Click on the Edit button to modify the basket : name, type, note, access privileges. And finally click on New basket to add a new basket.

sect4.title: Baskets contents
sect4.para: To consult the contents of a basket click on its name.

figure.title: Cataloguing > Baskets > Management > Manage baskets, basket contents

sect4.para: To remove an element from a basket click on its Remove from basket icon :
A basket can contain entries of the holdings (records, copies or periodical issues) :

Click on the "+" sign in front of a record to expand it. You can now consult the record in ISBD format as well as the list of hardcopies and e-copies. The record is displayed exactly like for search results (Cataloguing > Search).

However when loading the basket you may have scanned an item not belonging to your library (for instance, a book belonging to the County Public Library, and that was not imported into PMB). To help you keep track of these items, a basket can also contain unknown items :
In a basket, items that are tagged, are highlighted by an icon preceding their titles. For more information about tagging items, consult the section .

sect4.title: Modifying a basket
sect4.para: You can also modify a basket by clicking on the Edit button to the right of the screen.
The "Edit basket" screen allows you to modify the name and note of a basket as well as users access privileges to the basket.

You can see the basket type : records basket, issues basket, copies baskets. You cannot change the type of an existing basket. If you have made a mistake when creating the basket, delete it and create a new one.

Under "Access granted to" are check boxes corresponding to the access privileges. The names displayed are those of PMB authorized users. A simple user cannot revoke the access privileges of an administrator.
You can thus create a basket which will be accessible only to you (and the administrator).

sect4.title: Adding a basket
sect4.para: The "New basket" screen is almost identical to the "Edit a basket" screen with the following difference, the presence of the Delete button. For more information, consult above the section .

sect4.title: PMB default installed baskets
sect4.para: If your systems administrator installed PMB with the "essential data for a quick start" (feed_essential.sql, for more information, see the PMB Installation Guide), then several baskets will have been created to serve as examples or to facilitate the management of the library.

The For Exhibition records basket, for instance. Destiné à recevoir les notices d'une petite exposition, qui peut ensuite être mis en avant grâce aux étagères virtuelles de l'OPAC. Intended for receiving records for a small exhibition, it can later be highlighted via the virtual shelves in the OPAC. For more information consult

The Return to County Public Library records basket to facilitate management. Intended for receiving the bibliographic records of works to be returned to the County Public Library for databse cleanup after the items have been returned.

The Return to the County Public Library copies basket to facilatate management. Intended for receiving the copies of works to be returned to the County Public Library so as to discharge issues and cleanup the database after the items have been returned.
The Doubles on title records basket to facilatate management. Intended for receiving duplicate entries for database cleanup.
The Never loaned items basket to facilitate management. Intended for receiving items that have never been loaned.

sect3.title: Managing procedures
sect3.para: This screen displays the procedures associated with baskets. You can define procedures for filling up the baskets, for tagging items in baskets already filled up or for modifying records, periodical issues or copies of works stored in the baskets.
For more information on procedures (examples are provided ), consult below the section 3.5 How to use baskets section.

sect4.title: PMB default installed procedures
sect4.para: If your systems administrator installed PMB with the "essential data for a quick start" (feed_essential.sql, for more information, see the PMB Installation Guide), then several procedures are already created to serve as examples or to facilitate the management of the library.
EXPL by section/owner selection procedure by one or more sections for one or more owners.
EXPL class numbers starts with selection procedure by the first digits of a class number. Useful when making regular stocktakes of holdings by the library.
Copies for return to the County Central Library action procedure allowing a batch status change for all the copies of a basket.
Records by author selection procedure by one or more authors.
Duplicate records selection procedure by title.
Records with no copies associated selection procedure.
Never loaned selection procedure for works never loaned.

sect2.title: Collection
sect2.para: Collection here refers to the fill-up of a basket. You can fill a basket using a barcode reader (by scanning the barcodes of works). You can also place items in a basket by starting a selection procedure.
These procedures were defined in Baskets/Management/Manage procedures.
At any time in the Cataloguing tab whenever a basket-shaped icon is displayed, you can add an item (record, copy, issue) to a basket by clicking on the icon

sect3.title: Basket fill-up niceties
sect3.para: The fill-up functions of baskets correspond to the various possible operations :

listitem.para: adding a record to a copies basket = adding all the copies associated with the record to the basket
adding a copy to a records basket = adding the copy entry to the basket
adding an analytical record to an issues basket = adding the corresponding article to the basket

sect3.para: Warning : adding an issue to a records basketwill be without effect. Indeed, two types of notes correspond to an issue : the periodical main entry and the analytical entries of the issue.

sect2.title: Tagging
sect2.para: Basket tagging allows you to compare the contents of a basket with other elements, either manually (scanning) or by starting a PMB selection procedure.

sect3.title: By scan
sect3.para: Click on the name of the basket of which you want to tag the elements.

figure.title: Cataloguing > Baskets > Tag on/off > By scan

sect3.title: By selection
sect3.para: To tag a basket using the select function, click on it.

figure.title: Cataloguing > Baskets > Tag on/off > By selection

sect3.para: Next click on the procedure you want to use.

figure.title: Cataloguing > Baskets > Tag on/off > By selection, choosing the tagging procedure

sect3.para: Do not forget to adjust parameter values, if any.

figure.title: Cataloguing > Baskets > Tag on/off > By selection, tagging completed

sect3.para: The tagged elements of a basket are declared as Tagged. The total number of elements in the basket is shown. The elements belonging to the library registered in PMB are displayed on the second line of the summary table, at the bottom of the page.

sect2.title: Actions
sect2.para: From this screen, you can do the following :

listitem.para: modify the contents (HTML, Excel HTML, Excel XLS formats).
cleanup the selected basket
delete from the database all the elements in the basket
export the contents of the basket
transfer the contents of a basket into another
apply an SQL query to the contents of a basket

sect2.para: To perform all these operations, click on the corresponding links in the central interface and on a given basket name.

sect3.title: Editing
sect3.para: For more information on PMB's export formats, consult the PMB Administrator's Guide, Chapter 10 Export, section 1 File formats.
Next select the elements of the basket : tagged or untagged elements.

sect3.title: Cleaning up a basket
sect3.para: Basket cleanup allows you to clean a basket of its contents.
Next select the elements of the basket : tagged or untagged elements

sect3.title: Delete from database

figure.title: Cataloguing > Baskets > Actions > Deleting from database

sect3.para: Delete from database means deleting the elements of the selected basket (records, issues or copies) from the library database.
Use it with extreme care, for instance, to delete works lost.
Next select the elements of the basket : tagged or untagged elements.

sect3.title: Export
sect3.para: Export enables you to export the contents of a basket.
Next select the elements of the basket : tagged or untagged elements.

sect3.title: Transfer
sect3.para: Transfer enables you to transfer the elements of a basket (tagged or untagged) into another one.

sect3.title: By query
sect3.para: You can also apply an SQL query to the contents of a basket, for instance, an UPDATE query to change the call numbers of a set of works that have been moved to another section of your library. For more information about queries, consult the PMB Administrator's Guide).

sect2.title: How to use baskets
sect2.para: Here are some examples on how to use baskets. They will help you to better comprehend the use of PMB baskets as well as their powerful features via the queries.

sect3.title: Putting works with no copies associated into a basket

listitem.para: Create a records basket,
Create a selection procedure, enter the following code (CAUTION, no line break) :
listitem.programlisting: SELECT notice_id as object_id, 'NOTI' as object_type FROM notices left join exemplaires on notice_id=expl_notice WHERE expl_notice is null and niveau_biblio='m' and niveau_hierar='0'

listitem.para: Go to the basket > Collection > By selection and fill up your basket using this procedure

sect3.title: Stocktaking
sect3.para:
> I would like to simplify my inventory operations, so I > decided to create a basket to contain all the copies of a given section. I > should then be able to physically check all the works on a shelf and using > the action "Delete from the basket the tagged elements" I should be able to find the books > that are still in the database but are physically lost, stolen... > > I wanted to use a procedure but I am a real dummy! In the > SP I have an inventory of all my non-fiction works, for instance, but I have no idea > how to transform it to make it work in the baskets > Here is the corrected SS !
select expl_id as object_id, 'EXPL' as object_type from exemplaires, notices, docs_section where idsection in (!!section!!) and expl_notice=notice_id and expl_section=idsection order by section_libelle, expl_cote, expl_cb
All there is to do now is to set a value for the !!section!! parameter : a multiple choice list from a query with :
select idsection, section_libelle from docs_section order by section_libelle > Stephanie FORT > Librarian > > CDI - CollÃ¨ge Saint Pierre > Jette (Belgium)

sect1.title: Shelves
sect1.para: The virtual shelves are groups of records baskets that may or may not contain records. The virtual shelves allow you to display the records in the OPAC or on your web site. You can use this PMB feature to hold a virtual exhibition on your web site, display your latest acquisitions, a book club selections, etc ...

sect2.title: Management
sect2.para: Shelves management displays the list of existing shelves.
To create a new shelf, click on the Add a shelf button.
To modify an existing shelf, click on its corresponding line.

A shelf is defined by its name, a validity period, and its visibility on the OPAC home page. A note can also be added. Finally each shelf has its own access privileges, allowing authorized users to modify the given shelf and its contents.

sect2.title: Set up
sect2.para: The set up screen of a shelf makes it possible to add or remove the contents of one or more baskets from one of your virtual shelves.
Click on the shelf you wish to set up .
Then check the records baskets you wish to add to your virtual shelf.

figure.title: Cataloguing > Shelves > Set up, adding baskets to a shelf

sect2.para: Next click on Save to validate the set up of your virtual shelf.

sect2.title: Z39.50 Search
sect2.para: The Z39.50 search enables you to search for a work in the catalogue of another library and to integrate the catalogue record directly into the PMB catalogue. It spares you the onus of having to repeat the cataloguing processes already completed by the other library.

Note Bibliographical records are an intellectual creation and are protected by copyright. The records of the Library of Congress as well as those of the National Library of France are in the public domain : you can freely import them. Other libraries may have their own policies. Contact them for more information.
Example, let us import Germinal by Zola. As search criteria, select "title" and in the adjacent text box enter "Germinal".
Next select one or more libraries which may possibly have a copy of Germinal so it can be added to the catalogue.

figure.title: Cataloguing > Z39.50 > Search, intermediate screen showing progress

sect2.para: Whenever a request does not return any results after some ten seconds, we can assume that either our internet connection is saturated or that the host server is too busy to answer, or even that our PMB configuration is incorrect (if ever all of our z39.50 searches have not returned any results by then).
Lines starting with "Failure..." correspond to errors. An error message is then displayed. Here, a few examples :

listitem.para: Timeout : the server did not answer within the predetermined time interval
Connect failed : the server answered but the connection failed
Malformed query : the z3950 profile of the server is incorrect. Check the z3950 profile of the server with its systems administrator

sect2.para: Lines starting with COMPLETED indicate that the search was succesful. The number of results is indicated as END : the server returned X titles of Y found (limited to the first one hundred records, if you get more than a hundred results, refine your search).
Once the search is completed, click on "Results" to display the results.

figure.title: Cataloguing > Z39.50 > Search, search results screen

sect2.para: A screen then displays the search results. The results list shows records in ISBD format. Notes and other minor details do not appear in this list. To select a record, click on its title.

figure.title: Cataloguing > Z39.50 > Search, records modification screen before insertion

sect2.para: The record is displayed in edit mode so you can consult its details, modify it if necessary and integrate it into the catalogue. The edit screen is slightly different from the regular edit screen : authors and publishers have two entry fields corresponding to the principal element (last name) and the non-indexable element (first name). Once you have made the modifications, validate them by clicking on the "integrate this title" button.
The following screen allows you to define copies.

figure.title: Cataloguing > Z39.50 > Search, copies entry screen

sect2.para: Next catalogue your copies. Once a copy has been defined, click on Integration. You can also return to the results list and integrate an additional title from the results list.

On top of this screen, there is the message "title integrated", with a link View. The record is displayed in edit mode. The screen is the same as the "add record" screen (see above the sectionNew record).

sect3.title: Regular use of the Z39.50 search
sect3.para: For French libraries, the main interest in the Z39.50 search lies in the search by ISBN from the National Library of France (BnF). For your library's holdings, you can easily catalogue/classify them by scanning their commercial barcodes (EAN) with your barcode reader.
How-to

listitem.para: go to cataloguing > Z39.50 > Search
select BnF from among the servers,
make sure that the search criteria is ISBN
enter/scan the barcode of your work in the entry text box. The scanned EAN (commercial code) will be converted into an ISBN by PMB.

The search result for an ISBN is normally unique. Theoretically, no two works can have the same ISBN. On the other hand bibliographic records can be more or less detailed according to the selected host server.

sect3.para: You can then make copies for the searched work, and continue.
Note : the BnF has a turnaround for cataloguing operations. Latest publications (published less than a year ago) may not have been cataloged yet.
